LIN200.name: Introduction to Language
LIN200.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
LIN200.description: Linguistic structure of language. Applications of linguistics to other disciplines. Human and societal aspects of the nature, use, acquisition, and history of languages.

LIN225.name: Language and Gender
LIN225.description: Gender and language in societies around the world. Issues such as status, power and politeness in monolingual and multilingual societies. The role of gender in language development, language variation and language change.

LIN230.name: Languages of the World
LIN230.description: Develop an understanding and appreciation of the world’s linguistic diversity by exploring facts about languages of the world and an appreciation of linguistic diversity as part of cultural diversity. Learn about language families and historical relationships, as well as language typology. Explore how the language situation today reflects historical movements of people and their settlements. Symbolic functions of language and what happens when languages come in contact.

LIN291.name: Special Topics in Linguistics
LIN291.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
LIN291.description: Special topics supplementing regular course offerings proposed by faculty on a group study basis.

LIN401.name: Introduction to Linguistics
LIN401.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
LIN401.description: Basic goals, concepts, methods, and research results of modern theoretical and applied linguistics. Examples from a variety of languages.

LIN424.name: Introduction to Phonetics and Phonology
LIN424.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
LIN424.description: Phonetics, phonetics features and components, phonological phenomena, phonemic analysis, sound systems and data analysis.

LIN427.name: Laboratory Phonetics
LIN427.description: Basic concepts, principles and methods of modern phonetics. Understanding of what human speech is and how it works. Reflect on, analyze, and discuss their own speech and the speech of those around them.

LIN431.name: Introduction to Morphology
LIN431.description: Word structure, word formation, morphological analysis, interface with phonology and syntax, and theoretical issues in morphology. Data from diverse languages of the world.

LIN434.name: Introduction to Syntax
LIN434.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
LIN434.description: Structure of sentences and structural relations among phrases. Methods of syntactic analysis and argumentation.

LIN437.name: Semantics and Pragmatics
LIN437.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
LIN437.description: Structure of meaning in natural languages. Methods of semantic analysis and argumentation. Technical tools for stating precise and falsifiable semantic hypotheses.
LIN437.prerequisite: LIN 200 or LIN 401 or approval of department

LIN450.name: Child Language Acquisition
LIN450.description: Linguistic issues, perspectives and research on the acquisition of language by children. Phonology, lexicon, morphology, syntax, semantics. Universal principles, variation, contexts. Implications for related disciplines.

LIN455.name: Neurolinguistics
LIN455.description: Theoretical approaches to the study of language and the brain. Perspectives on normal and impaired linguistic functioning offered by lesion studies and brain-imaging techniques. The genetic basis of language as evidenced in family and twin studies.

LIN463.name: Introduction to Cognitive Science
LIN463.description: Cognitive processing of information by animals, humans, and computers. Relevant issues in philosophy, linguistics, psychology, neurophysiology, and artificial intelligence.

LIN471.name: Sociolinguistics
LIN471.description: Linguistic and social psychological bases for language choice. Accounts of language variation and related larger constructs such as speech community, communicative competence, dialect, and language change.

LIN484.name: Data Analysis for Linguists
LIN484.description: Develop proficiency in statistical techniques, data munging/cleaning and data management.

LIN490.name: Independent Study
LIN490.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
LIN490.description: Special projects arranged by an individual student and a faculty member in areas supplementing regular course offerings.

LIN491.name: Special Topics
LIN491.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
LIN491.description: Special topics supplementing regular course offerings proposed by faculty on a group study basis.

LIN499.name: Senior Thesis Research (W)
LIN499.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
LIN499.description: Individual research project supervised by a faculty member. Demonstration of student's ability to conduct independent research and prepare an undergraduate thesis.
LIN499.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I writing requirement.
LIN499.restrictions: Open to seniors. Approval of department.

LIN499E.name: Senior Thesis for Experiential Learning
LIN499E.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
LIN499E.description: Individual research project supervised by a faculty member. Conduct independent research. Prepare an undergraduate thesis. Present at a conference or other public forum.
LIN499E.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
LIN499E.restrictions: Open to seniors. Approval of department.

LIN824.name: Phonological Theory I
LIN824.description: Major phonological theories, argumentation, and advanced skills of phonological analysis.

LIN825.name: Phonological Theory II
LIN825.description: Issues in phonology. Current controversies and trends of research in phonology.

LIN834.name: Syntactic Theory I
LIN834.description: Theories, current issues, and research of the structure of sentences and structural relations among phrases. Methods of syntactic analysis and argumentation.

LIN835.name: Syntactic Theory II
LIN835.description: Issues in syntax. Current research and controversies.

LIN837.name: Advanced Studies in Semantics and Pragmatics
LIN837.description: Selected topics in semantics and/or pragmatics, such as noun phrase interpretation, tense and aspect, conversational implicature, and negation. Advanced level analytical techniques.

LIN850.name: Advanced Studies in Child Language Acquisition

LIN855.name: Advanced Studies in Neurolinguistics
LIN855.description: Study of the computation of language in the brain and its contribution to understanding brains and language. Lesion research and research using neuroimaging techniques such as Magnetoencephalography (MEG), Electroencephalography (EEG), Positron Emission Tomography (PET), functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI), and Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS).

LIN867.name: Nature and Practice of Cognitive Science
LIN867.description: Survey of how different disciplines explore the cognitive processes underlying intelligent behavior.

LIN871.name: Advanced Studies in Sociolinguistics
LIN871.description: Linguistic and societal bases for language choice. Topics exemplifying modern sociolinguistics, including concerns of power, ethnicity, gender, quantitative microsociolinguistics, field techniques, and data analysis.

LIN881.name: The Structure of a Non-European Language
LIN881.description: Survey of the structure of a non-European language such as Amharic, Chinese, Japanese, or Hausa. General overview of the language, including history, phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, pragmatics, discourse, and variation. Particular attention to the features generally nonexistent in European languages.

LIN890.name: Independent Study
LIN890.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
LIN890.description: Special projects, directed reading, and research arranged by an individual graduate student and a faculty member in areas supplementing regular course offerings.

LIN891.name: Special Topics
LIN891.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
LIN891.description: Special topics supplementing regular course offerings proposed by faculty on a group study basis for graduate students.

LIN892.name: Seminar in Linguistics
LIN892.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
LIN892.description: Directed original research on current topic in linguistics.
LIN892.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Linguistics major.

LIN898.name: Master's Research
LIN898.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
LIN898.description: Directed research in support of Plan B master's degree requirements.

LIN899.name: Master's Thesis Research
LIN899.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
LIN899.description: Directed research leading to a master's thesis, used in partial fulfillment of Plan A master's degree requirements.

LIN991B.name: Topics in Comparative Literature
LIN991B.description: Critical approaches to genre, periodization, and influence in English and other literatures.

LIN999.name: Doctoral Dissertation Research
LIN999.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
